title: How do writers respond to audience expectations?
key: how-do-writers-respond-to-audience-expectations
parentKey: how-is-writing-a-social-activity
points:
  - point: >-
      Meeting the needs and expectations of audiences gives writing more impact,
      but sometimes it is difficult to know what audiences expect.


      **FOR INSTRUCTORS**: Student writers will face many choices in engaging
      with their audiences. 


      [In thinking about their audiences, some students might shift between
      different kinds of academic and non-academic
      writing.](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.25) 


      For example, as [Lizzie Hutton and Gail Gibson
      found](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.25), "students who
      align their writing development with the 'academic' tend to see writing as
      constituting the communication of thought" (90).


      In other words, some students prefer to write in ways that match the
      writing of a particular style or discipline (e.g., science).


      On the other hand, "students who talked about their growth as writers as
      more closely tied to the 'creative' tend to understand writing instead as
      constituting the generation of thought" (90). 


      In this case, some students prefer to write in a way that creates new
      ideas.


      Using different kinds of writing helps us reach audiences in different
      ways.


      Asking students to write about who their audience is and how they are
      reaching them can help them align their writing with readers they
      envision.


      As [Ryan McCarty’s chapter shows, students’ experiences and perspectives
      of their roles as writers and their writing influence the way they see
      their audiences.](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.30) 


      > [I think more of a development, because it was a different form of
      writing. It also helped me reflect upon the way we write in science.
      Between the two, it showed me how I can communicate effectively when we do
      talk about—okay, so you’re talking to more of a lay audience as opposed to
      the scientific community in communicating your research. Let’s look at
      different ways to read and
      write.](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.30)
    title: What are our audiences’ expectations?
  - point: >-
      Writing **to** others means communicating ideas to a specific person or a
      specific group of people.


      As Anne Gere’s chapter shows, Stephanie reflects on how she uses writing
      as a trade credit underwriter to speak to her readers.


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="Now%20I%20am%20doing%20more%20analytical%2C%20a%20lot%20of%20persuasive%20writing%20%u2026"
      fullText="%5BHere%u2019s%20what%20I%20recommend.%20Here%20are%20seven%20or%20eight%20bullet%20points%20of%20financial%20ratios%20%20and%20%20positive%20or%20negative%20news%20and%20press%20releases.%20Here%u2019s%20%20how%20the%20soybean%20crop%20is%20going%20in%20Brazil%20and%20all%20that%u2026%20diplomatic%20emails%20to%20%20brokers%2C%20the%20people%20who%20stand%20between%20us%20and%20our%20clients%2C%20trying%20to%20sugarcoat%20the%20no%u2019s%20and%20make%20the%20yes%u2019s%20kind%20of%20sound%20like%20we%u2019re%20doing%20them%20a%20favor.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.37%29"


      Writing **for** others can mean making communication accessible to as many
      readers as possible.


      Let’s consider Dan, who uses social media to reach out to his audience.


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="I%20am%20seeing%20a%20lot%20of%20upcoming%20writers%20or%20a%20lot%20of%20upcoming%20students%20%u2026"
      fullText="%5Bbecause%20they%u2019re%20interacting%20with%20me%20on%20Twitter%20on%20an%20everyday%20basis%20or%20on%20Facebook%u2026%20Social%20media%u2014I%20like%20to%20think%20of%20it%20as%20talking%20from%20a%20position%20of%20power.%20You%20can%20say%2C%20%u2018Why%20don%u2019t%20you%20look%20at%u2026%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.38%29"


      When we write __to__ our audiences, we call their attention in some way,
      and when we write __for__ our audiences, we invite them into our writing.
      In either case, we are thinking about different ways of engaging with
      them.
    title: Are we writing to or for audiences?
  - point: >-
      Reaching audiences can depend a lot on kinds of writing and purpose.


      One challenge is knowing which kinds of writing are appropriate for the
      audiences being addressed.


      Consider Kris, who finds the language of science to be a necessary step in
      her development as a writer.


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="At%20first%20when%20I%20was%20starting%20to%20read%20papers%20..."
      fullText="%5BAt%20first%20when%20I%20was%20starting%20to%20read%20papers%20I%20thought%20scientists%20used%20unnecessarily%20large%20words%20to%20describe%20things.%20Then%20what%20I%20found%20as%20I%20started%20writing%20was%20that%20we%20have%20a%20specific%20vocabulary%2C%20just%20like%20any%20field%20does%2C%20and%20it%u2019s%20just%20way%20easier%20to%20communicate%20in%20that%20way.%20You%20can%20use%20one%20word%20to%20describe%20what%20would%20have%20to%20be%20used%20as%20a%20whole%20sentence.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.29%29"


      Another challenge is making sure purposes for writing are clear to
      audiences.


      Consider Kaitlin, who explores how her [multimodal
      purposes](/pages/writing-involves-choices/how-do-we-write-in-the-digital-age/what-is-multimodal-composition-and-where-do-people-encounter-it/#what-counts-as-multimodal-composition)
      affect how her audiences think about traveling.


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="I%20would%20pick%20out%20quotes%20where%20it%20was%20making%20the%20point%20that%20I%20wanted%20..."
      fullText="%5BI%20would%20pick%20out%20quotes%20where%20it%20was%20making%20the%20point%20that%20I%20wanted%20but%20over%20an%20image%2C%20so%20you%u2019re%20not%20just%20immediately%20assaulted%20with%20a%20ton%20of%20text.%20You%20have%20%20to%20%20scroll%20%20over%20%20it%20%20to%20%20see%20%20it%u2026%20%u2018Why%20do%20people%20adventure%2C%20and%20what%20do%20they%20know%20that%20I%20don%u2019t%3F%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.35%29"


      And so, we make our writing matter for our audiences by making choices
      about style and delivery.


      [One way we can determine how well our writing is addressing our audiences
      is by having other people take a look at
      it.](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1KBpTwBrxv_NuFW9xCcvWBDIlUMQ-IrSnp-8T-U0Lpi8/edit#bookmark=id.6qky7jevpdp0)
    title: How can we make writing matter for audiences?
  - point: >-
      Writers make important decisions about what to write and for whom. Click
      on the options below to see relationships between writing situations and
      writers: identities, the topic, and who the readers are.

      <Game2 />


      <Activity>
    title: Putting it all together
afterPoints: >-
  Good writers think about their audiences’ needs and expectations, including
  how choices they make can meet those needs and expectations.
---
In our study, we learned that we think about the needs and expectations of our readers by making decisions about the kind, the direction, and the purpose of our writing.

points.point:
Meeting the needs and expectations of audiences gives writing more impact, but sometimes it is difficult to know what audiences expect.

**FOR INSTRUCTORS**: Student writers will face many choices in engaging with their audiences. 

[In thinking about their audiences, some students might shift between different kinds of academic and non-academic writing.](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.25) 

For example, as [Lizzie Hutton and Gail Gibson found](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.25), "students who align their writing development with the 'academic' tend to see writing as constituting the communication of thought" (90).

In other words, some students prefer to write in ways that match the writing of a particular style or discipline (e.g., science).

On the other hand, "students who talked about their growth as writers as more closely tied to the 'creative' tend to understand writing instead as constituting the generation of thought" (90). 

In this case, some students prefer to write in a way that creates new ideas.

Using different kinds of writing helps us reach audiences in different ways.

Asking students to write about who their audience is and how they are reaching them can help them align their writing with readers they envision.

As [Ryan McCarty’s chapter shows, students’ experiences and perspectives of their roles as writers and their writing influence the way they see their audiences.](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.30) 

> [I think more of a development, because it was a different form of writing. It also helped me reflect upon the way we write in science. Between the two, it showed me how I can communicate effectively when we do talk about—okay, so you’re talking to more of a lay audience as opposed to the scientific community in communicating your research. Let’s look at different ways to read and write.](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.30)
